subject: AgitarOne's licence
msgSnippet: ... I expect it to remain that way. I like your product, at least what I ve been able to use of it so far, and the Agitar folks I ve worked with have been
messageBody:
albsavoia wrote:

> > I think I understand the antiquated licence scheme it's meant to
> > replace, but I would rather pay a tiered subscription fee based on a
> > measure of how much I use the software (say, the number of outcomes it
> > detects?), rather than what the resulting design looks like.
> >
> > > Anyway, objection noted. Thanks.
> >
> > You're welcome, and thank you for noting it. I know it's a knotty
> > problem to solve. I can't claim to know better, but I know what I don't
> > like, and I don't like this (quite). Of course, I'm not exactly in
> > Agitar's market for this product right now, so my opinion is largely
> > theoretical in nature at present.
>
> Hi J.B.,
>
> As Agitar's co-founder and CTO, I always hesitate to jump into product
> discussions in this forum; but in this case it might be useful to
> clarify some things. Especially since the discussion seems to be
> quite civilized so far :-).

I expect it to remain that way. I like your product, at least what I've
been able to use of it so far, and the Agitar folks I've worked with
have been excellent. You even hired someone recently I'd worked with at
another of my clients, and he's excellent, so your hiring practices are
sound. :)

> >so my opinion is largely
> >theoretical in nature at present.
>
> Thank you for recognizing that, but I can see how (based on the brief
> description of our pricing model) you would reach your conclusions -
> so we have to fix that and be clearer.
>
> In practice, the number of classes on which the license is based is
> measured more in orders or magnitudes than an very precise class
> count.

I suspected as much, but in any such scheme, eventually I will "run out
of classes", even if that number is 10,000 or 100,000. It will happen
less frequently, sure, but the limit is nevertheless still there.

> Many of our licenses are actually enterprise-wide and for an
> unlimited number of users or classes.

I suspected as much, but I can only imagine where the price-point is for
the "all access pass" for AgitarOne. I'm sure it's suitably high for the
very high value you provide.

> In all cases, there is ample
> head-room for adding new classes and refactoring big-old-nasty
> classes. As a matter of fact, one of the top uses for our JUnit
> generation is to help create a safety net for working with legacy
> code; and class/method refactoring is one of the things that we
> recommend. You can see me giving a demo of exactly that type of
> refactoring (at the method level) at:
>
> http://www.agitar.com/solutions/products/agitarone_demos.html
> <http://www.agitar.com/solutions/products/agitarone_demos.html>

I have no doubt as to the effectiveness of your product. I even support
it as an indispensable tool for rescuing legacy codebases. I wish more
people would use it that way, than see it as a replacement for writing
tests (in general).

> (It's the first of the four mini-demos on that page ... No making fun
> of my accent please, and NO we did not hire Borat to do the voice over
> :-)).
>
> Every pricing scheme has advantages and disadvantages. Most of us
> want to move away from per-seat licensing. I believe that a
> server-based solution with an unlimited number of classes (or with a
> very generous over-allotment for growth and refactoring) is a step in
> the right direction, but we are open to exploring other suggestions
> (like the one you already made).

As I wrote, I don't know of a better solution; I just know I don't like
a limit on the number of classes. There has to be a better way, but in
the meantime, AgitarOne's value mostly exceeds this annoyance. I suppose
it would matter much more to me if I had a licence for up to 10,000
classes, had 9,997 classes in my system and no more money to give you.
Since I'm not in that situation, I can't say much more. It might be a
case of "Funny, it has never come up."

Take care, Alberto.
